most in dark souls it's sort of noted as the hardest game the hardest game series that's out there
and it's my favorite game series i play with my friends i'm the kind of person who goes and does challenge runs we do drinking games when we play if you die
you drink and then we all just fall asleep at the end of the night but one of the things i sort of realized
when i started playing this game more seriously is it is probably the least accessible thing that's out there and so i have a
brother he's about 15 years younger than me he lives with autism in a few different physical disabilities and i was playing
minecraft with him one day and sort of came to the realization like he's he's not going to be able to play a game like
this and it's not because he doesn't have the reaction time it's not that he doesn't have the patience to sort of put
into it to learn every person's move and get through the level one by one but it's because the actual number of
actions you have to take on a tiny tiny little controller is almost impossible for him so i started to sort of explore new
concepts to be able to make dark souls a game that he could play ideally with me with my friends with the
rest of my family as well my other brothers and sister and so my first thought was like what if i could make a game that could help play dark souls for
me and then introduce it to my brother and that sort of started as a pretty wild concept kind of sounds like
cheating in most video games and there's a few cases where we build stuff that is basically cheating but my goal is to get to something that actually worked that i
could hand him and let him use to play a game and i'm going to share a couple different failures along the way in
terms of how we go from this sort of wild concept to working software and eventually to a real product that's helping people now so a couple rules no
hacks or mods you can't change the game code we can't run this against a modded version of dark souls it should just
work out of the box has to be able to kind of work with other games at least be extendable uh it doesn't have to be

essentially what you do is you take different frames of images and you do object recognition training where you

gigantic computer vision model that i would then run on my same pc that i was playing the game on to be able to detect

xbox adapter controller this thing is amazing it's essentially it acts like a real xbox controller but
rather than having joysticks and buttons and triggers it has these little inputs you can bring your own buttons
you can use ones that are built by other manufacturers logitech makes a few i think samsung just released a couple so
you can have like buttons that are completely custom set up in order to act as inputs take for example this one in
the top left where he's got the the yellow button on his head rest meaning that he can hit his head to the left and
that would be the same as me using a controller with my hands to hit the y button uh custom joysticks buttons on a
pad and everything else and it allowed you to adapt the controller to the way that you wanted to play it was amazing
there's other tools in gaming specifically as well if you're using xbox you can use cortana for voice commands help you sort of open a game
real quick you don't have to go through menu navigation there's code gaming which is basically two people with two
different controllers acting and controlling the same person there's skill-based matchmaking and online gaming meaning if you're not as
good because of a disability specifically you're not going to get put into the same lobby with pros who are going to roll over you and a lot of
first-person shooters and as well as role-playing games there's also game difficulty settings you can turn it down to easy mode you don't have to play on
the hardest difficulty but dark souls doesn't have them we'll get back to that there's a lot of groups out there doing amazing work in this
space ablegamers charity is one that i work with they do some awesome work with they're also the co-inventors of the xbox
adaptive controller but they also will go and help people set up their devices to work best for them they'll meet them
at the hospital if you just had a spinal injury if you have cerebral palsy they'll be able to go help you get your
configuration working for you there's people like special effect out of the uk same sort of idea warfighter engaged
which works with injured veterans from war and then the cerebral palsy foundation obviously working specifically with
people with cp so okay there's something there there's a gap still because those people even with those devices cannot keep the same
pace as someone like me being able to claw my hand on on a controller or being able to use a keyboard and mouse there's

that's all sort of handled but it's a lot of back and forth that sort of happened automatically and it's kind of a pain for the user but once you're done
you're good and so what that looks like now is on the dot net side just setting up their authentication or authorization

essentials web authenticator i hit my endpoint i call sign in with my client id

speech recognition before this is what i do in my day job uh but this is what a sort of traditional speech recognition
approach looks like we detect that we need to start recording the audio that might be pressing the button that might just be when the app starts start
recording the audio we're then listening for the audio recording we detect that they've stopped speaking usually by
volume right so okay you've stopped at the end of your sentence you've got like you know maybe 100 to 500 milliseconds
to say okay you're done we send that whole audio chunk to some other service to process the speech
what i wanted to focus on instead was something more predictive in real time uh or automatic and so what essentially
that means is it's always on we're always recording but rather than waiting for you to stop speaking and then sending the chunk up we're sending
everything through the processor which is running on the device itself i don't have to stream that to someone else it's
entirely offline rather than having to run it from azure then back down to a windows device which then is sending to
arduino running everything on a raspberry pi which has enough compute to be able to support a speech and image recognition
model at the same time it also means i don't have to pay anyone i'm not streaming anything to azure you buy a
raspberry pi and you can run this offline and start speaking to it right away which is pretty cool with the microphone anyway
the performance is insane so that jump jump jump example i gave you with the action uh cueing that we had before

seconds from start of speech jump jump jump that first j sound to actually
executing a game 1.5 seconds was the fastest the average is like 5 seconds with predictive asr i know the second
you're saying jump before you've even finished pronunciating the p sound at the end of the first jump which means i
can execute all three within 30 milliseconds if you can send it fast enough and again all offline

we then have the device basically send the status back like hey i am listening now
